title: 114_hr4847
content: The Act may be cited as the "Correcting Unfair Benefits for Aliens Act of 2016" or the "CUBA Act of 2016." Congress finds that on July 1, 2015, President Obama announced the reopening of embassies and restoration of diplomatic ties between Cuba and the United States. Diplomatic relations were formally reestablished on July 20, 2015. Additionally, Texas saw a significant increase in the number of Cubans trying to enter the United States in 2015 compared to the previous year. The Obama Administration has reestablished relations with Cuba, impacting the special treatment Cuban nationals receive under the Cuban Adjustment Act. The special treatment Cuban nationals receive under various immigration policies is no longer applicable, as Congress believes they should be treated the same as nationals of other countries with diplomatic relations with the United States. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF THE CUBAN ADJUSTMENT ACT. Repeals the Cuban Adjustment Act and related statutes. Effective immediately for aliens admitted or paroled after enactment. SEC. 4. CERTAIN ACTIVITIES RESTRICTED. SEC. 4. CERTAIN ACTIVITIES RESTRICTED. No funds, resources, or fees may be used to implement policy changes related to the "Cuban Family Reunification Parole Program" as outlined in a memorandum from the Director of United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement. SEC. 5. CERTAIN CUBANS ENTRANTS INELIGIBLE FOR REFUGEE ASSISTANCE. Title V of the Refugee Education Assistance Act of 1980 is amended to remove references to Cuba and Cubans. Additionally, the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended in a similar manner. The Refugee Education Assistance Act of 1980 and the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 are amended to remove references to Cuba and Cubans. The amendments specify that the term "Cuban and Haitian entrant" should be replaced with "Haitian entrant" in relevant sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act. These changes apply only to nationals of Cuba entering the United States after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. REPORT. The Inspector General of the Social Security Administration must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment, detailing the enforcement methods for the requirement under section 416.215 of title 20, Code of Federal Regulations.
